Class ElevatorAPI

java.lang.Object
ElevatorAPI
public class ElevatorAPI extends Object

The ElevatorAPI class serves as the primary high-level interface for controlling and monitoring the elevator's physical components. It abstracts away the direct Modbus communication details by utilizing an an instance of GenericAPI.

This API provides specific methods for elevator operations such as controlling motor speeds, managing door states, reading various sensors (floor, door), and performing system resets. Each method translates an elevator-specific command into one or more low-level Modbus calls via the `GenericAPI` instance, making the elevator's logic independent of the underlying communication protocol.

  • Field Details

    • api

      public GenericAPI api
      An instance of GenericAPI which provides the direct interface to the Modbus TCP/IP server. This `api` object is responsible for handling all low-level communication like writing to coils and registers, and reading input states, allowing `ElevatorAPI` to focus on elevator-specific logic.

  • Constructor Details

    • ElevatorAPI

      public ElevatorAPI() throws UnknownHostException, IOException, de.re.easymodbus.exceptions.ModbusException
      Constructs a new ElevatorAPI instance. During instantiation, it initializes the underlying GenericAPI object, which in turn attempts to connect to the Modbus TCP/IP server. This establishes the communication link necessary for all subsequent elevator operations.
      Throws:
      UnknownHostException - If the Modbus server's hostname cannot be resolved during GenericAPI initialization.
      IOException - If an I/O error occurs during the Modbus client connection.
      de.re.easymodbus.exceptions.ModbusException - If a Modbus-specific error occurs during the connection process.

  • Method Details

    • setCrawl

      public void setCrawl(int speed) throws Exception
      Sets the elevator's crawl speed. "Crawl speed" refers to a very slow, precise movement used for fine positioning, typically when approaching a floor to align perfectly. This method directly writes the specified speed value to a Modbus holding register designated for crawl control.
      Parameters:
      speed - An integer value representing the desired crawl speed. A value of 0 typically indicates stopping crawl movement. Positive values for upward crawl, negative for downward.
      Throws:
      Exception - If an error occurs during the underlying Modbus communication (e.g., network issues, Modbus protocol errors) when setting the register.

    • motorOn

      public void motorOn(int speed, boolean value) throws Exception
      Controls the main elevator motors based on a specified speed category and a boolean value. This method maps abstract speed categories (fast up/down, slow up/down) to specific Modbus coils which control the corresponding motor contactors or drives.
      • `speed == 2`: Fast speed for moving upwards.
      • `speed == 1`: Slow speed for moving upwards (often used for precision or nudge).
      • `speed == -2`: Fast speed for moving downwards.
      • `speed == -1`: Slow speed for moving downwards (often used for precision or nudge).
      Parameters:
      speed - An integer representing the motor speed category (2, 1, -2, -1).
      value - A boolean value indicating whether to turn the motor on (`true`) or off (`false`).
      Throws:
      Exception - If an error occurs during the underlying Modbus communication when setting the coil.

    • pulseMotor

      public void pulseMotor(int speed) throws Exception
      Sends a momentary "pulse" to a specific motor control coil based on a speed category. This method simulates a brief activation of a motor (e.g., a short nudge), by turning the corresponding coil ON for 300 milliseconds and then turning it OFF. This is useful for precise, short bursts of movement, particularly for fine adjustments. The method uses specific coil mappings that correspond to different motor speed and direction controls.
      • `speed == 2`: Pulses the coil for fast upward movement.
      • `speed == 1`: Pulses the coil for slow upward movement.
      • `speed == -2`: Pulses the coil for fast downward movement.
      • `speed == -1`: Pulses the coil for slow downward movement.
      Parameters:
      speed - An integer representing the motor speed category (2, 1, -2, -1) to be pulsed.
      Throws:
      Exception - If an error occurs during the underlying Modbus communication when setting the coil or if the thread is interrupted during the sleep delay.
      See Also:
      • GenericAPI.setCoil(int, boolean)

    • isDoorOpen

      public boolean isDoorOpen()
      Checks the current status of the elevator's door to determine if it is fully open. This is achieved by reading the state of a specific Modbus discrete input coil that corresponds to the "door open" sensor on the PLC.
      Returns:
      `true` if the door open sensor is active (indicating the door is fully open), `false` otherwise.

    • isDoorClosed

      public boolean isDoorClosed()
      Checks the current status of the elevator's door to determine if it is fully closed. This is achieved by reading the state of a specific Modbus discrete input coil that corresponds to the "door closed" sensor on the PLC.
      Returns:
      `true` if the door closed sensor is active (indicating the door is fully closed), `false` otherwise.

    • sensorTriggered

      public boolean sensorTriggered(int address)
      Reads the state of a general Modbus discrete input sensor at a given address. This method provides a generic way to query the binary status (ON/OFF) of any digital input connected to the PLC, such as floor sensors, safety switches, or internal flags.
      Parameters:
      address - The Modbus address of the discrete input sensor to be read.
      Returns:
      `true` if the sensor at the specified address is active (ON), `false` otherwise.

    • openDoor

      public void openDoor() throws Exception
      Initiates the process to open the elevator door and waits until the door is confirmed open. This method repeatedly pulses the Modbus coil associated with the "open door" command and pauses briefly (200 milliseconds) between pulses until the `isDoorOpen()` sensor reports that the door has reached its fully open position. This loop ensures robust door operation.
      Throws:
      Exception - If any error occurs during the underlying Modbus communication (e.g., network issues, Modbus protocol errors) when pulsing the coil or checking door status, or if the thread is interrupted.
      See Also:
      • GenericAPI.pulseCoil(int)
      • isDoorOpen()

    • closeDoor

      public void closeDoor() throws Exception
      Initiates the process to close the elevator door and waits until the door is confirmed closed. This method repeatedly pulses the Modbus coil associated with the "close door" command and pauses briefly (200 milliseconds) between pulses until the `isDoorClosed()` sensor reports that the door has reached its fully closed position. This loop ensures reliable door closure.
      Throws:
      Exception - If any error occurs during the underlying Modbus communication (e.g., network issues, Modbus protocol errors) when pulsing the coil or checking door status, or if the thread is interrupted.
      See Also:
      • GenericAPI.pulseCoil(int)
      • isDoorClosed()

    • reset

      public void reset() throws Exception
      Performs a comprehensive reset of the elevator's operational state, bringing it to a safe, known condition. This involves: 1. Turning off all motor control coils to ensure the elevator is stationary. 2. Setting the crawl speed to zero. 3. Pulsing a specific Modbus coil (typically a master reset or emergency stop acknowledge). 4. Ensuring door control coils are in a neutral/off state. This method aims to clear any active commands and prepare the elevator for new operations.
      Throws:
      Exception - If any error occurs during the underlying Modbus communication when sending reset commands (e.g., network issues, Modbus protocol errors).

    • getCurrentFloor

      public int getCurrentFloor()
      Determines the current floor of the elevator by checking the status of dedicated floor sensors. It iterates through a predefined array of Modbus input addresses, each corresponding to a floor sensor. The method returns the floor number (1-4) for the first sensor that is found to be active (triggered). This approach assumes that only one floor sensor should be active at any given time when the elevator is precisely aligned with a floor.
      Returns:
      The integer representing the current floor number (1-4) if a sensor is triggered, or -1 if no floor sensor is currently active, indicating the elevator might be between floors or an issue with sensor readings.
